Las estrellas brillaban y las hojas de los árboles se rozaban con un ruido muy triste; allá lejos se oía un búho que ululaba porque se había muerto alguien y un chotacabras y un perro que gritaban que se iba a morir alguien más, y el viento trataba de decirme algo y yo no entendía lo que era, de forma que me daban calofríos. es_results_raw: de vuelta a la isla, que ella misma vendría a buscarme. Me dio un abrigo y me despidió con un beso en la frente. Me puse el abrigo y me lancé al agua. Estaba muy cansado, pero sabía que tenía que seguir adelante. Comencé a caminar por la costa, buscando algún pueblo o aldea donde pudiera encontrar ayuda. Después de un rato, vi un humo en el cielo y supe que había un pueblo cerca. Me dirigí hacia allí y pronto vi las casas y las gentes. Me acerqué al primer casa que vi y llamé a la puerta. Me abrió un hombre y le dije que venía de la isla y que necesitaba ayuda. Me miró con sorpresa y me preguntó qué pasaba. Le conté todo y me dijo que no se preocupara, que él me ayudaría. Me llevó a su casa y me dio de comer y de beber. Después, me llevó al pueblo y presentóme a los demás. Todos se ofrecieron a ayudarme y me dijeron que no me preocupara, que encontrarían ayuda para mis amigos. Me sentí muy agradecido y les dije que les estaría siempre agradecido. Pasé varios días en el pueblo, esperando a que llegara la ayuda. Finalmente, un día vimos un barco en el horizonte. Era un barco de rescate y venía a buscarnos. Me puse muy contento y corrí a la costa a esperar a mis amigos. Cuando llegaron, nos abrazamos todos y nos alegramos de vernos de nuevo. Les conté todo lo que me había pasado y les presenté a los gentes del pueblo. Todos se alegraron de conocernos y nos dieron las gracias por haberlos ayudado. Después, nos subimos al barco y nos fuimos de la isla. Nunca olvidaré la aventura que viví en aquella isla desierta y a los gentes que me ayudaron a salir de allí.

Y así, seguíamos adelante, disfrutando del paisaje y de la tranquilidad del río, hasta que llegamos a nuestro destino, donde nos esperaban nuevas aventuras y desafíos. Pero siempre recordaríamos la soledad del río, y la sensación de estar solos en el mundo, rodeados de la belleza y la tranquilidad de la naturaleza.

Just as I was passing a place where a kind of a cowpath crossed the crick, here comes a couple of men tearing up the path as tight as they could foot it.

en_results_raw: They were armed to the teeth, and looked like they hadn't been out of the woods in a month. I reckon they were after something, or somebody. I pulled my canoe up amongst the willows and set there perfectly still, holding my breath. They come along, and when they got pretty close to me, one of them says, "I'm afraid we've lost the trail." The other one says, "I'm afraid you're right," and they both stopped and looked around. I was shaking like a leaf, but I didn't make a sound. They stood there a spell, and then they sat down on a log, and I heard one of them say, "Well, we might as well rest a spell." I was in a mighty bad fix, I can tell you. I didn't know what to do. I was afraid to move, and I was afraid to stay still. I was in a regular quandary. I reckon I set there for an hour, holding my breath and hoping they'd go away. But they didn't seem to be in no hurry. They set there and talked, and I could hear every word they said. They were talking about somebody they were after, and they said they'd get him before they were done. I didn't know who they were after, but I knowed it wasn't me, and that was all I cared about. I was just fixing to make a break and get away, when I heard one of them say, "I'm hungry." The other one says, "I'm hungry too." And they both got up and started to look around. I reckon they were looking for something to eat. I knowed I had to get out of there, and I knowed I had to get out of there mighty quick. So I pushed my canoe out into the crick, and got in and started to paddle away as quiet as I could. I didn't dare to look back, but I could hear them hollering. I reckon they seen me, and I reckon they were after me. I paddled as fast as I could, and I didn't stop till I was plumb tuckered out. I got out of the canoe and set down on the bank, and I didn't move for an hour. I was too tired, and I was too scared. I didn't know what to do, and I didn't know where to go. I was in a mighty bad fix, and I didn't know how to get out of it.

en_first_half: The crowd washed back sudden, and then broke all apart, and went tearing off every which way, and Buck Harkness
en_second_half: he heeled it after them, looking tolerable cheap. I could a staid if I wanted to, but I didn’t want to.
en_results: was left standing there, staring after them, his face pale and his eyes wide with wonder. He couldn't believe
en_results_raw: was left standing there, staring after them, his face pale and his eyes wide with wonder. He couldn't believe what he had just seen. One minute the crowd was cheering and the next they were running for their lives. He looked around, trying to make sense of it all, but there was no one in sight. The street was empty, littered with discarded hats and scarves, and the only sound was the distant rumble of feet and the occasional shout. Buck took a deep breath, trying to calm himself down, and began to walk in the direction the crowd had gone. As he walked, he noticed that the streets were getting progressively more and more crowded, and he could hear the sound of sirens in the distance. He wondered what was happening, and whether he should be worried. Suddenly, he heard a voice behind him. "Hey, you! Yeah, you with the funny hat! Where do you think you're going?" Buck turned to see a tall, burly man with a thick beard and a menacing scowl on his face. He looked like he hadn't smiled in years, and Buck could tell that he wasn't in the mood for jokes. "I...I was just trying to find out what's going on," Buck stuttered, trying to sound calm. The man snorted. "You don't know what's going on? You're not from around here, are you?" Buck shook his head, feeling a sense of trepidation. "No, I'm from...from out of town." The man nodded, his expression unreadable. "I figured as much. Well, let me tell you something, friend. You're in the middle of something big here. Something that could get you killed." Buck's eyes widened as the man turned and disappeared into the crowd, leaving him standing there, feeling more lost and alone than ever.

en_results_raw: so bad. I was out in de woods, pickin' some herbs for my wife's sick sister, when I heard dat noise. I dropped my basket en ran towards de sound, my heart racin' like a wild animal. When I got to de bank, I saw sumpn that made my blood run cold. It was my little 'Lizabeth, lyin' on de ground, her eyes closed en her body still. I rushed to her side en picked her up, callin' out her name, but she didn't respond. I knew right den en dere dat sumpn was wrong, en I felt a pain in my heart like I never felt before. I held her close en started to cry, callin' out for help, but nobody came. The silence was oppressive, and I found myself straining to hear any sound that might break the stillness. But there was nothing. I shivered, despite the warmth of the sun, and turned away from the window to face the room once more. That was when I saw it. A piece of paper, folded up and left on the coffee table.
